abstracts.cdata!:
The Fourth Roads Rehabilitation and
            Maintenance Project for Nicaragua received a highly
            satisfactory outcome with moderate risk to development
            outcome. Both the Bank and the Borrower received
            satisfactory ratings for their performances. The project
            underwent eight restructurings and received additional
            financing (AF). The first restructuring reflect the use of
            Force Account as an additional procurement method for the
            implementation of civil works under the project. Increase in
            construction costs in Nicaragua led to the second
            restructuring due to high costs the funds available under
            component 2 could only finance 198 km of rural roads
            stabilization with adoquines instead of 320 km originally
            planned. Thus, the intermediate indicator target for km of
            rural roads stabilized under the Rural Transport Improvement
            component 2 was reduced from 320 to 198 km. The project was
            restructured a third time due to the increase in
            construction costs due to world wide price escalation. The
            project results framework was revised and the closing date
            was extended to December 31, 2012. The project closing date
            was further extended two more times: (i) due to the delays
            in the procurement of contractor for the road construction
            works on the Nueva Guinea Naciones Unidas section financed
            under the AF. Other restructuring included reallocation of
            proceeds among various categories to allow efficient
            completion of the project activities. The last restructuring
            canceled the undisbursed balance due to lack sufficient time
            to receive any procured goods before project closing date
            and given that the project achieved its PDO and all results
            targets. There were several lessons learned from this
            project including the following: (1) the long term track
            record of the Banks engagement and coordinated efforts in
            the countrys road sub-sector provides robust platform for
            well performing performance of projects, (2) a functional
            Road Maintenance Fund is a key pillar for long-term
            sustainability of the road sector, (3) application of the
            innovative adoquines and Modulos Comunitarios de Adoquinado
            (MCA) model is highly appropriate for rural road
            improvements with emphasis on the poor regions, (4) projects
            that promote womens participation generate important
            benefits to the recipient population, (5) to encourage
            impact evaluations in transport projects, significant
            support and assistance should be incorporated in the project
            design, (6) the use of MCAs is a technically feasible method
            that also provides a number of employment and skills
            building benefits, and (7) Creation of rural road
            maintenance microenterprises based on trained staff of MCAs
            can help ensure sustainability of the model after the construction.
